results.title: [Construction of the Water Tower at Fletcher Jones Factory, Warrnambool, 1967]
results.brief_description:
The Fletcher Jones factory and Gardens at 61–81 Flaxman Street, Warrnambool (established 1948) are famous local landmarks and symbolic of the radical approach to industrial relations and the provision of workplace amenities taken by the famous Australian company. The complex, including the Water Tower, was listed on the Victorian Heritage Register in 2006 in recognition of its historic and social significance which notes “…the unusual and successful integration of surplus military structures, buildings and modernist facade in a factory setting. They reflect the resourcefulness and dynamism of Fletcher Jones in the use of war surplus structures and objects during a time of building material shortages.”

The forty-metre-high water tower – built for fire protection and as a booster system – was designed and supervised by Ralph Jones Construction Engineering Services between 1965–1967. [Source: University of Melbourne Archives: Ralph Jones Water Tower Submission and Business Papers].

This silent, black-and-white footage of the tower’s construction was photographed by Australian photographer Robert Lennox Suggett. It is a unique historic documentary record of the construction of an iconic feature of Warrnambool’s – and Victoria’s – industrial heritage.

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection]
results.material_description:
5 x 400ft 9.5mm B&W silent home movies
7 x 8mm reels (4 x 100ft, 2 x 400ft)
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

Charles Edward Hayes was born on 28th March 1914 and grew up in Port Melbourne. In 1928 he joined Johns & Waygood in City Road, South Melbourne where he worked his way up from office boy to the machine shop becoming a fitter. In 1942 he was nominated to take charge of Johns & Waygood Munitions Annex in Montague making 10lb mortar bombs.

In the late 1940s, Charles purchased his first 9.5mm movie camera starting a hobby that would bring years of enjoyment. In November 1949 Charles purchased an Austin A40 car which he kept until 1973 – it also makes an appearance or two in the home movies! On the 11th November 1950, the family purchased a property at Miller Road, Heathmont, comprising 5 acres of land. They decided to build some sheds and try at being poultry farmers. Charles continued travelling to South Melbourne to work until 1956 when they became full time farmers.

Over the years the family had numerous cows, duck, pigs, sheep, dogs, cats and of course Ticka the cockatoo; all these animals were treated as pets. For socialising and fitness Charles with his wife Elsie, joined the local tennis club and enjoyed playing at the weekend. In 1958 Charles joined the Ringwood Movie Club through some friends and enjoyed the friendship of the club and continued to record their travels with his trusty home movie camera. In 1966 Charles went on to work for Nutritional Products in Mitcham, so they eased out of the poultry business.

Their daughter Olwyn married John Baker on the 9th July, 1967 and had two sons. Elenor married Ron Peach on 2nd April 1970 and had two daughters – Elenor kindly donated the films to ACMI. Elise and Charles were happily married more than 50 years, until he passed away in 1993. These films remain testament to a happy and hard-working family from Melbourne’s outer eastern suburbs.

This home movie collection was donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter, Elenor Peach.

images.caption: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 3] (Charles Hayes) Digital Access Still

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows the Hayes family on a holiday when they are young parents with their young daughters. The family travels to The Grampians (Gariwerd/Geriwerd), the coastal town of Warrnambool, and the Eildon Weir and Eildon Lake, all in Victoria, before heading to Sydney in New South Wales.

Scenes from a zoo at the time could be distressing to some viewers as contemporary zoological standards are very different to those of the early 1950s.

Originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 children and their parents on board a carnival train ride and the young Hayes girls with enormous bows in their hair stand for the camera, one very unsure and one laughing
00:00:22:00 riding on top of an elephant and monkeys swinging in their cage, followed by goats, a glimpse of a hippopotamus, bears, swimming penguins and a pacing tiger
00:02:26:00 the young Hayes girls sit with their father on a bench
00:02:30:00 Mr and Mrs Hayes and one of the girls at a lookout over a mountain range, likely to be The Grampians (Gariwerd/Geriwerd) in Victoria
00:02:55:00 wandering along creeks and bush and near dramatic waterfalls
00:03:41:00 family members smile at the camera, some lovely sunglasses and one of the Hayes girls shows her tiny handbag to the camera
00:04:00:00 one of the children hand feeds a bottle of milk to a lamb before taking it for a walk on a lead followed by some horse riding lessons
00:04:52:00 a lovely country house set against the mountains in the immediate background and an array of 1940s to 1950s cars parked alongside
00:05:42:00 a sign ‘Silverband Falls’
00:06:07:00 hand feeding cows with food scraps
00:06:30:00 community races for children and adults
00:07:23:00 views of the Eildon Weir and boats on Lake Eildon
00:08:00:00 the girls sit on some used cable spools
00:08:23:00 a small candlelit memorial to King George VI
00:08:30:00 swimming in a pool while an airplane flies overhead
00:09:20:00 a large ferry and the Sydney Harbour Bridge from a distance and up-close followed by street scenes in Sydney
00:10:26:00 beachgoers on the sand, possibly at Manly in Sydney and a family and or friends gathering for the camera
00:11:10:00 views of Sydney’s older city buildings including the AWA building and tower (Amalgamated Wireless Australasia)
00:11:15:00 the koala enclosure at the zoo followed by more elephant rides

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows a family holiday along the east coast of Australia, beginning with the suspension bridge and dramatic cascades of water at the Hume Weir on the Victorian and New South Wales (NSW) border.

The family travels on to Timbertown near the town of Wauchope in NSW. Developed as a re-creation of an 1880-1910 working timber settlement, the tourist attraction ‘Timbertown’ was opened in the 1970s with some original buildings and some built to historic plans.

We also see a restored steam train, ‘The Green Hornet’ travel through bushland, a group of working bullocks and a glimpse of whip cracking. It’s then on to the Big Banana at Coffs Harbour, a Sikh Temple in NSW and some bushwalking.

Originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:16:00 footbridge over the Hume Weir
00:00:30:00 close-up of the Hume Weir slipway followed by views around the Weir works
00:01:45:00 pelicans on the water
00:02:02:00 ‘Timbertown’ sign and a steam train with a great example of 1970s fashion ‘flares’ being worn in the foreground
00:02:15:00 children looking around ‘Timbertown’
00:02:25:00 a team of bullocks on a dusty road accompanied by a man carrying a large axe, followed by an old fashioned horse and cart
00:02:55:00 a demonstration of manual short plank splitting
00:03:25:00 children enjoy a ride through the trees on a steam train
00:03:50:00 whip cracking exhibition followed by ‘The Green Hornet’ in close up as it steams by
00:04:15:00 close up of the bullock yoke workings followed by a demonstration in a small arena of the bullocks team at work hauling a single large log
00:05:11:00 ‘The Big Banana’ and admirers at Coffs Harbour
00:05:40:00 sign for ‘The Vincent Tree’ after which the camera pans up a very tall tree trunk
00:06:54:00 botannical sign for ‘Yellow Carabeen Sloanea Woollisii’ and views of the tree
00:07:30:00 the family pose in the stocks of an old set of buildings which could be Middle Head Fort on the NSW coast
00:08:29:00 seabirds and various views of coastline and sea
00:09:13:00 the family on the beach
00:09:20:00 sign for the ‘Guru Nanak Sikh Temple’ rests on a brick wall, followed by the Temple
00:09:58:00 dramatic views of a ravinne and waterfall
00:10:30:00 children playing in an ‘Apex Park’ playground

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 6]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

A short film which features the early stages of construction of the West Gate Bridge in Melbourne made more dramatic by being filmed from overhead, through a window of an airplane.

We see a Trans Australia Airlines (TAA) airplane in the film, one of Australia’s domestic airlines between its inception in 1946 and its merger with Qantas in September 1992.

There are also scenes of life at home in Heathmont in Melbourne’s southeast, including family members modelling dresses, menswear and tennis gear for the camera.

Originally made using Standard 8mm film. Note that the film goes unexpectedly dark for several seconds at 00:2:12:00.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 landing gear of a plane filmed through a window during takeoff
00:00:13:00 landing gear retracting as plane rises into the air
00:00:28:00 residential areas in Melbourne (likely to be Essendon) filmed from overhead
00:00:35:00 views of each end of the Westgate Bridge during construction
00:01:17:00 a container ship in Port Phillip Bay
00:01:40:00 plane landing gear being lowered
00:01:54:00 passengers alighting from a TAA airplane on the tarmac (likely a Lockheed Electra Mk2 Aircraft)
00:02:44:00 women of the family modelling dresses walking toward the camera
00:03:25:00 showing the pets in the garden
00:04:23:00 the camera pans out over the residential fringe, capturing a view of the Dandenong Ranges in the distance
00:05:24:00 a view of the front of the Heathmont family home
00:05:31:00 women of the family modelling bathing suits of the day walking from and toward the camera
00:05:56:00 a classic car model from the 1940s
results.description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

A short film which features the early stages of construction of the West Gate Bridge in Melbourne made more dramatic by being filmed from overhead, through a window of an airplane.

We see a Trans Australia Airlines (TAA) airplane in the film, one of Australia’s domestic airlines between its inception in 1946 and its merger with Qantas in September 1992.

There are also scenes of life at home in Heathmont in Melbourne’s southeast, including family members modelling dresses, menswear and tennis gear for the camera.

Originally made using Standard 8mm film. Note that the film goes unexpectedly dark for several seconds at 00:2:12:00.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 landing gear of a plane filmed through a window during takeoff
00:00:13:00 landing gear retracting as plane rises into the air
00:00:28:00 residential areas in Melbourne (likely to be Essendon) filmed from overhead
00:00:35:00 views of each end of the Westgate Bridge during construction
00:01:17:00 a container ship in Port Phillip Bay
00:01:40:00 plane landing gear being lowered

00:02:44:00 women of the family modelling dresses walking toward the camera
00:03:25:00 showing the pets in the garden
00:04:23:00 the camera pans out over the residential fringe, capturing a view of the Dandenong Ranges in the distance
00:05:24:00 a view of the front of the Heathmont family home
00:05:31:00 women of the family modelling bathing suits of the day walking from and toward the camera
00:05:56:00 a classic car model from the 1940s

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film opens with a ‘red rattler’ train at Lilydale station, in Victoria. It is Christmas Day in 1970 and the filmmaker’s daughter Elenor Peach and her husband Ron are boarding the train. The ‘red rattler’ was the name affectionally given to the ‘Tait carriage’ wooden-bodied electric trains that ran in metropolitan Melbourne, Victoria, from 1919 to the early 1980s (named after the then Commissioner of Railways Sir Thomas Tait).

Most of the film captures a holiday around regional Victoria and include great examples of holiday life in the 1970s, such as men’s and women’s bathing suits, sunglasses, sunhats, beach umbrellas, surfing, picnics and station-wagon cars for travelling and camping at a creek among Australian tea trees.

Originally made using Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 a wonderful close-up of a ‘red rattler’ train pulled up at a station
00:00:25:00 a group of holiday makers sitting on camp chairs next to a creek
00:00:35:00 collecting water from the creek
00:00:57:00 close-ups of the holiday makers including a wonderful example of a handmade 1960s/1970s gingham smocking hat
00:01:50:00 a young woman in a bikini bathing suit and bathing cap enters the fast running creek water
00:02:12:00 swimming and a close-up of the 1960s/1970s rubber bathing cap which is covered in pink flowers
00:02:18:00 looking through insect netting to a man holding a baby (which lends an interesting effect)
00:02:45:00 young men in ‘cut off shorts’ fixing a Holden model car
00:02:53:00 lovely intergenerational picture of a very young baby held by an elderly age man who is wearing braces (rather than a belt)for his trousers of an earlier era
00:03:17:00 swimming along the creek and sitting on the bank
00:04:22:00 focus on a full head of hair ‘curlers’ as used at the time
00:04:29:00 views of rocky terrain and bush and a woman with a camera takes a photo of the filmmaker
00:05:45:00 rock climbing and views the Grampians mountain range (Geriwerd, Gariwerd) in Western Victoria
00:08:19:00 views of the township of Stawell in regional Victoria
00:08:58:00 title ‘Seascape’ written in sand followed by views of the sea and coastline, likely to be around the coastal town of Lorne in Victoria
00:09:55:00 surfboards strapped to a van followed by golfing on a cliff overlooking the sea
00:10:05:00 views of surfers in the water, a swimmer walking from the sea to her towel and the group of holiday makers sitting on the sand under a beach umbrella
00:10:46:00 taking a shot through a camera on a tripod on the sand
00:11:38:00 colourful beach umbrellas and bathers with a car of the era in the background
00:12:37:00 a roadside picnic
00:12:57:00 wonderful example of decorative sunglasses of the era
00:13:17:00 title ‘The End’ written in the sand

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993).The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows a little of suburban life in Heathmont when it was first being developed. We see some examples of vintage cars as they were at the time. One of the residents is a young Ron Barassi of Australian Rules Football fame, and Victorian of the Year in 2009, who lived in Heathmont from 1957 to the late 1970s when he moved to St Kilda in Melbourne.

Indoor scenes of the family home show family members with some of their many pets a highlight of which is a game of table tennis with their pet cockatoo and cat.

The film includes a trip to the beach with some some great examples of vintage bathing suits.

Also seen in the film are the Gas and Fuel Corporation buildings on Flinders St which were built in 1967 and demolished in 1997 to make way for the current Federation Square in Melbourne.

Another glimpse of Melbourne’s history flashes across the family television screen - the logo for ‘Channel O’ which was the precursor to the current Channel 10 television station.

There is also a segment showing a small or home based packaging business for what appears to be health food products. The film ends with some travel scenes.

Originally made using Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:01:34:00 Gas & Fuel building on the site of current Federation Square
00:01:49:00 Ron Barassi standing in front of his home
00:08:55:00 Ticka the cockatoo and the family cat play table tennis with the family
00:11:16:00 home based health food business in production at the kitchen table

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This is a composite film of different segments – a family reunion at Halls Gap in 1973 where we see typical barbeques of the era – a small round three legged hotplate and a ‘trough’ style both stacked with 1970’s barbeque fare – lots of lamb chops. We also see the fashions of the 1970’s in the velvets, flares, knee high socks and long hair. ‘Sandown Park with Jack Brabham’ introduces a segment of vintage racing cars and favourite car driver of the day, Jack Brabham signing autographs and smiling at the camera.

The film also includes some Moomba parade floats and marching girls, some city scenes of Melbourne and the Yarra Heliport and Ansett-ANA helicopter and finishes with some up close footage on the set of ‘World of Sport’, a very popular television sports show of the era featuring Lou Richards, Jack Dyer and Ron Casey among others.

Originally made using Standard 8mm film.

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 3. Moomba 1964] [excerpt]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This is an excerpt from Reel 3 showing Melbourne’s Moomba street parade 1964, featuring colourful parade floats, marching girls, musicians and popular personalities of the day. The floats are assembled at the top of Swanston St before they head off for the big parade.

results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film contains some of the Hayes family favourites – their assorted pets including the star of many of the films, Ticka the cockatoo, their farm animals and views of the areas surrounding their home in Heathmont. There is also a brief visit to the beach.

A feature of the film is some early views of Ringwood shops and traffic including good examples of cars of the day and the very new looking ‘Holden Bill Paterson Motors’. Bill Paterson was a successful racing car driver of his era. We also see advertising signs of the day such as ‘Whelan the Wrecker’ and ‘Dickies’ and a vintage ‘red rattler’ train crossing the Yarra so likely to be the Port Melbourne/St Kilda line now a lightrail.

Originally made using Standard 8mm film.

7 x 8mm reels (4 x 100ft, 2 x 400ft)
